subject: Art
title: Fat Over Lean
description: The essential oil painting rule that prevents cracking.

hook.text: Old oil paintings crack. Not all â€” just the ones where the artist broke a simple rule: fat over lean. Each successive layer must contain MORE oil (fat) than the one beneath. Ignore this and your painting self-destructs.

buildup.text: Why it matters: oilier layers dry slower and remain flexible. Leaner layers dry faster and become rigid. If a rigid lean layer sits ON TOP of a flexible fat layer, the rigid top cracks as the bottom layer shifts during drying.

discovery.text: Practice: first layers â€” thin paint with solvent (lean, fast-drying, rigid). Middle layers â€” paint with less solvent (medium). Final layers â€” paint with added oil or medium (fat, slow-drying, flexible). Each layer is oilier than the last.

twist.text: Alla prima (one-session) oil painting bypasses this rule entirely â€” if everything is wet at once, there are no layers to conflict. Fat over lean only matters for multi-session paintings where earlier layers dry between sessions.

climax.text: Plan a painting in three layers: 1) thin, solvent-heavy underpainting (lean â€” dry overnight). 2) Standard paint consistency (medium). 3) Final touches with added medium or oil (fat). Your painting will stay intact for centuries.

punchline.text: Fat over lean is time-management for paint. Get the layers right and your painting outlives you.

quiz.question: What does 'fat over lean' mean in oil painting?
options: Each successive layer should contain more oil than the previous one to prevent cracking as layers dry at different rates
